# allowBannedProperties()

Disables BabyHint's banned properties.

This function is not intended for production use. The program will be restarted for changes to take effect.

View Source essentials-x.js, line 5688

Example
document;
// expected error: 'document is a reserved word.'

// 1. Comment out the banned properties
// document;
allowBannedProperties();

// 2. Uncomment the banned properties
document;
// no expected error

# angularGradient(x, y, width, height, startColor, endColor, angleopt, stepopt)

Draws an angular gradient from startColor to endColor in the form of an ellipse.

For a step size greater than 1, the function draws triangles of base step. Using a step size greater than 1 is faster. It is highly advised to store drawn gradients in images using the get function for use in a draw loop. Use the smooth function to prevent jagged edges.

Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Default Description
x number

x-coordinate of the top-left corner the gradient

y number

y-coordinate of the top-left corner the gradient

width number

width of the gradient

height number

height of the gradient

startColor color

starting color

endColor color

ending color
angle number <optional>
 0

start angle of the gradient in degrees

step number <optional>
 5

step size

View Source essentials-x.js, line 2716

Examples
angularGradient(25, 25, 100, 100, RED, YELLOW);
// expected outcome: angular gradient from red to yellow
angularGradient(150, 25, 100, 100, PURPLE, PINK, 90);
// expected outcome: angular gradient from purple to pink rotated 90 degrees
angularGradient(275, 25, 100, 100, GREEN, LIGHTBLUE, 0, 25);
// expected outcome: angular gradient from green to light blue in strips of thickness 25

# clean(fn) → {function}

Removes Khan Academy's loop protection code from functions.

Khan Academy adds a few lines of code to every function created to prevent the webpage from freezing. This can be a hinderance when running more resource-intensive code.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
fn function

Function to be cleaned

View Source essentials-x.js, line 573

Cleaned function.

function
Examples
const drawEllipses = function() {
    for (let i = 0; i < 1e4; i++) {
        ellipse(Math.random(0, width), Math.random(0, height), 10, 10);
    }
};
// possible error: 'A for loop is taking too long to run.'
const drawEllipses = clean(function() {
    for (let i = 0; i < 1e4; i++) {
        ellipse(Math.random(0, width), Math.random(0, height), 10, 10);
    }
});

# drawElement(elopt, settingsopt) → {string}

Creates an HTML element and "draws" it on top of the canvas.

If no jQuery object is provided an empty <div> element is created that contains HTML provided in the data parameter.

By default, elements are interactive, meaning they block canvas interaction directly under them. Set the interactive settings to false to allow for click-through canvas interaction instead.

Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Default Description
el jQuery <optional>

jQuery object
settings Object <optional>
data string <optional>

HTML
id string <optional>

HTML id
x number <optional>
 0

x-coordinate of the element

y number <optional>
 0

y-coordinate of the element

width number <optional>
 'max-content'

width of element

height number <optional>
 'max-content'

height of element

interactive boolean <optional>
 true
css Object <optional>
See:
  • removeElement
  • clearElements

View Source essentials-x.js, line 5785

id

string
Examples
const el = $('<p>', {
    text: 'Hello World'
});
drawElement(el);
// expected outcome: 'Hello World' element drawn at the top-left corner
const el = $('<p>', {
    text: 'Hello World'
});
drawElement(el, {
    x: 100,
    y: 100
});
// expected outcome: 'Hello World' element drawn at (100, 100)
drawElement({
    data: '<p>Hello World</p>',
    x: 100,
    y: 100
});
// expected outcome: 'Hello World' element drawn at (100, 100)
const el = $('<p>', {
    text: 'Hello World',
    css: { color: 'red' }
});
drawElement(el);
// expected outcome: 'Hello World' element drawn at the top-left corner in red
drawElement({
    data: '<p>Hello World</p>',
    css: { color: 'red' }
});
// expected outcome: 'Hello World' element drawn at the top-left corner in red

# effect(filter, …args)

Applies CSS effect on the canvas.

The effect function is much more efficient than the Processing version. Since Processing by default does not clear Canvas filters, wrap effect calls in push/pop, or use the clearEffects function.

Unlike their Processing counterparts, effects are applied to everything drawn after the effect function is called.

To use CSS properties directly, see the MDN documentation on CanvasRenderingContext2D.filter.

Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Description
filter string

Either BLUR, BRIGHTNESS, LUMINANCE, CONTRAST, DROP_SHADOW, GRAY, GRAY_SCALE, HUE_ROTATE, INVERT, OPACITY, SATURATE or SEPIA.

args * <repeatable>

View Source essentials-x.js, line 2921

# font(name, sizeopt, …properties) → {font}

Sets font, size and other CSS font properties.

Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Description
name string | font

Name of font or font

size number <optional>

Font size
properties string <repeatable>

CSS font properties

View Source essentials-x.js, line 4112

Created font

font
Examples
fill(BLACK);
font('Arial', 30, 'bold');
text('Hello World', 100, 100);
// expected outcome: 'Hello World' in bold Arial font
const arialBold = font('Arial', 'bold');
textSize(30);
text('Hello World', 100, 100);
// expected outcome: 'Hello World' in normal Arial normal size font
// `textSize()` should not be used with `font()`

// Instead, use `font()`
font(arialBold, 30);
text('Hello World', 100, 200);
// expected outcome: 'Hello World' in bold Arial size 30 font
// Use the `-call` parameter to prevent the font automatically being set
// This functionality is useful when defining font variables
const serif = font('serif', '-call');
text('Hello World', 100, 100);
// expected outcome: the text will still be in normal Arial font
font(serif);
text('Hello World', 100, 200);
// expected outcome: the text will be in serif font
const arialBoldItalic = font('Arial', 'bold', 'italic');
text('Hello World', 100, 100);
// expected outcome: 'Hello World' in bold and italic Arial font

// Use the negate syntax to remove properties from fonts
font(arialBoldItalic, '-bold');
text('Hello World', 100, 200);
// expected outcome: 'Hello World' in italic Arial font

# forceAllowScroll()

Removes all 'wheel' event handlers attached to the canvas.

allowScroll only removes the event handler that prevents the page from being scrolled, however if the program is edited or restarted this is no longer possible.

This function is not intended for production use.

See:
  • allowScroll
  • preventScroll

View Source essentials-x.js, line 5528

# formatDuration(ms, precisionopt, rawopt) → {string|Array}

Converts milliseconds to a readable format of duration.

Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Default Description
ms number

duration in milliseconds

precision number <optional>
 1e-3

nearest number to round to in terms of milliseconds

raw boolean <optional>
 false

return raw values

View Source essentials-x.js, line 4214

Readable format of duration.

string | Array
Examples
const martianDay = 88775244;
console.log(formatDuration(martianDay));
// expected output: '1 day, 39 minutes, 35 seconds, 244 milliseconds'
const earthDay = 86399999.9466;
console.log(formatDuration(earthDay, 1e3 * 60 * 60 * 24));
// expected output: '1 day'
const moonRotation = 27.322 * 24 * 60 * 60 * 1000;
console.log(formatDuration(moonRotation, 1e3, true));
// expected output: [0, 0, 27, 7, 43, 41, 0, 0]

# formatNumber(n, localesopt, optionsopt) → {string}

Converts a number to a more readable format.

Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Default Description
n number
locales string | Array <optional>
 'en'
options Object <optional>

View Source essentials-x.js, line 4270

string
Examples
const n = 123456789;
printf('%', formatNumber(n));
// expected output: '123,456,789'
const n = 1234.56789;
printf('%', formatNumber(n));
// expected output: '1,234.568'
printf('%', formatNumber(n, 'en', { minimumFractionDigits: 5 }));
// expected output: '1,234.56789'
const n = 123456789;
printf('%', formatNumber(n, 'uk'));
// expected output: '123 456 789'
const n = 1000;
printf('%', formatNumber(n, 'en', { style: 'currency', currency: 'usd' }));
// expected output: '$1,000.00'

# inherit(subClass, superClass)

Efficiently inherits properties from the parent class to the child class.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
subClass function

Class to be inherited to

superClass function

Class to inherit from

View Source essentials-x.js, line 721

Example
const Element = function(x, y, w, h) {
    this.x = x;
    this.y = y;
    this.w = w;
    this.h = h;
};
Element.prototype.draw = function() {
    rect(this.x, this.y, this.w, this.h);
};
const Button = function(x, y, w, h) {
    Element.call(this, x, y, w, h);
};
inherit(Button, Element);

const b = new Button(100, 100, 150, 50);
b.draw();
// expected outcome: rectangle with arguments (100, 100, 150, 50)

# linearGradientOld(x, y, width, height, startColor, endColor, directionopt, stepopt)

Draws a linear gradient from startColor to endColor in the form of a rectangle.

For a step size greater than 1, the function draws rectangles of width step. Using a step size greater than 1 is faster for all but diagonal gradients. It is highly advised to store drawn gradients in images using the get function for use in a draw loop.

Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Default Description
x number

x-coordinate of the gradient

y number

y-coordinate of the gradient

width number

width of the gradient

height number

height of the gradient

startColor color

starting color

endColor color

ending color
direction LEFT | RIGHT | TOP | UP | BOTTOM | DOWN | TOP_LEFT | TOP_RIGHT | BOTTOM_RIGHT | BOTTOM_LEFT <optional>
 RIGHT

direction of gradient

step number <optional>
 5

step size
Deprecated:
  • since 2.0.0

View Source essentials-x.js, line 3832

Examples
linearGradient(25, 25, 100, 100, RED, YELLOW);
// expected outcome: linear gradient from left to right; red to yellow
linearGradient(150, 25, 100, 100, PURPLE, PINK, TOP_RIGHT);
// expected outcome: linear gradient from bottom-left to top-right; purple to pink
linearGradient(275, 25, 100, 100, GREEN, LIGHTBLUE, BOTTOM_RIGHT, 10);
// expected outcome: linear gradient from top-left to bottom-right; green to light blue in strips of thickness 10

# mostPerformant(fns, iterationsopt, timingsopt) → {number|Array}

Calculates fastest function in terms of iterations.

The functions will be called n number of times. Their times will be how long they took to run n number of times. The more iterations, the more accurate the result.

Running resource-intensive function may result in an infinite loop error. This can be can bypassed using the clean function.

Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Default Description
fns Array

Functions to be compared

iterations number <optional>
 1e4

Number of times function should be called

timings boolean <optional>
 false

Return array of timings

View Source essentials-x.js, line 865

Index of fastest function or array of timings

number | Array
Examples
const testees = {
    'debug': debug,
    'console.log': console.log
};
const result = mostPerformant(Object.values(testees));
console.log(Object.keys(testees)[result] + ' performed faster.');
// possible output: 'console.log performed faster.'
const testees = {
    'ellipse': function() {
        ellipse(100, 100, 100, 100);
    },
    'rect': function() {
        rect(100, 100, 100, 100);
    }
}
const results = mostPerformant(Object.values(testees), 1e3, true)
results.forEach(function(result, i) {
    printf('%: %ms', Object.keys(testees)[i].padEnd(8), result)
});
// example output: `
// ellipse : 3.0350000597536564ms
// rect    : 3.325000172480941ms
// `

Examples

    x: 10,
    y: 10,
    width: 100,
    height: 100,
    stops: [
        RED,
        BLUE
    ]
});
// expected outcome: radial gradient from red to blue

    x: 10,
    y: 10,
    width: 100,
    height: 100,
    stops: [
        [0, '#F00'],
        [.5, GREEN],
        [1, '#00F']
    ]
});
// expected outcome: radial gradient from red to to green to blue

# radialGradientOld(x, y, width, height, startColor, endColor, stepopt)

Draws a radial gradient from startColor to endColor in the form of an ellipse.

For a step size greater than 1, the function draws ellipses of width step. Using a step size greater than 1 is faster. It is highly advised to store drawn gradients in images using the get function for use in a draw loop.

Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Default Description
x number

x-coordinate of center of the gradient

y number

y-coordinate of center the gradient

width number

width of the gradient

height number

height of the gradient

startColor color

starting color

endColor color

ending color
step number <optional>
 5

step size
Deprecated:
  • since 2.0.0

View Source essentials-x.js, line 3961

Examples
radialGradient(100, 100, 100, 100, RED, YELLOW);
// expected outcome: radial gradient from red to yellow
radialGradient(250, 100, 100, 100, PURPLE, PINK, 10);
// expected outcome: radial gradient from purple to pink with step size 10

# rectangle(x, y, width, height, tlopt, tropt, bropt, blopt)

Alias for rect with smart radius parameter defaults.

The rectangle will have a default corner radius of 0, if one argument is provided all corners are set to match that radius. If two arguments are provided, the top two corners' radius is set to the first parameter and the bottom two, the second. If three arguments are provided, the last argument--bottom-left corner--is defaulted to 0. If all four radius arguments are provided each corner will be set to it's corresponding parameter.

Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Default Description
x number

x-coordinate of the rectangle

y number

y-coordinate of the rectangle

width number

width of the rectangle

height number

height of the rectangle

tl number <optional>
 0

radius of top-left corner

tr number <optional>
 0

radius of top-right corner

br number <optional>
 0

radius of bottom-right corner

bl number <optional>
 0

radius of bottom-left corner

See:
  • square

View Source essentials-x.js, line 5245

Examples
rectangle(50, 50, 100, 50);
// expected outcome: Rectangle with side lengths 100 and 50
rectangle(150, 50, 100, 50, 10);
// expected outcome: Rectangle with radius 10 for all corners
rectangle(250, 50, 100, 50, 10, 0);
// expected outcome: Rectangle with radius 10 for top corners
rectangle(50, 150, 100, 50, 10, 10, 10); 
// expected outcome: Rectangle with radius 10 for all but bottom-left corner
rectangle(150, 150, 100, 50, 10, 10, 0, 10);
// expected outcome: Rectangle with radius 10 for all but bottom-right corner

# timeTaken(callback, idopt)

Measures the time it takes for a function to execute and logs to browser console.

Name Type Attributes Description
callback function

id string <optional>

Custom ID for multiple consecutive tests

View Source essentials-x.js, line 1049

Examples

    for(let i = 0; i < 1e3; i++) { println(i); }
});
// possible output: 'timeTaken#default: 1000.000000000000 ms'

    for(let i = 0; i < 1e3; i++) { println(i); }
}, '1000');
// possible output: 'timeTaken#1000: 1000.000000000000 ms'

    for(let i = 0; i < 1e2; i++) { println(i); }
}, '100');
// possible output: 'timeTaken#100: 100.000000000000 ms'

# wordWrap(str, max, bropt)

Wraps a string to a given number of characters using a string break character.

Name Type Attributes Default Description

max number

Maximum number of characters per line

 '\n'

Custom break character

View Source essentials-x.js, line 4808
